question:
Which of the following is the correct statement?

SSC CPO 03/10/23 (Afternoon)
option_1: The unit of power is joule/newton
option_2: Joule is the unit of work
option_3: The unit of energy is the watt
option_4: Joule second is also a unit of energy
solution:
• Joule is the SI unit of work as well as energy.
  • Work is defined as force × displacement, and its unit is newton × meter = joule.
  • Therefore, statement (b) is correct.

Option Analysis:

  • (a) Joule/newton: This simplifies to meter, not a unit of power.
  • (c) Watt is the SI unit of power, not energy.
  • (d) Joule-second is not a unit of energy; it is used in quantum mechanics (e.g., Planck's constant), not for measuring energy.

Additional Information:

  • Power = Work / Time, and its unit is watt (W).
  • 1 joule = 1 newton × 1 meter

question:
Which of the following is an INCORRECT match?

SSC CPO 04/10/23 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Let's evaluate the SI units of each quantity:
    • (a) Force – Newton → ✔ Correct
      • SI unit of force is Newton (N)
      • 1 N = 1 kg·m/s²
    • (b) Pressure – Pascal → ✔ Correct
      • SI unit of pressure is Pascal (Pa)
      • 1 Pa = 1 N/m²
    • (c) Work done – Joule → ✔ Correct
      • SI unit of work is Joule (J)
      • 1 J = 1 N·m
    • (d) Volume – Meter → ✖Incorrect
      • SI unit of volume is cubic meter (m³), not meter (m)
      • "Meter" is the unit of length, not volume.

Correct Answer:(d) is the incorrect match

question:
1 kilowatt is equivalent to:

SSC CPO 05/10/23 (Morning)
solution:
• 1 kilowatt (kW) = 1000 watts
  • 1 watt = 1 joule/second
  • Therefore,
  • 1 kilowatt = 1000 joules/second
  • Now, convert to kilojoules per hour:
    • 1000 joules/sec×3600 seconds=3,600,000 joules/hour1000 \, \text{joules/sec} \times 3600 \, \text{seconds} = 3,600,000 \, \text{joules/hour}1000joules/sec×3600seconds=3,600,000joules/hour
    • 3,600,000 J=3600 kJ3,600,000 \, \text{J} = 3600 \, \text{kJ}3,600,000J=3600kJ

So, 1 kilowatt = 3600 kJ/h

Option Analysis:

  • (a) 7200 kJ/h – ❌ Too high
  • (b) 3600 kJ/h – ✔ Correct
  • (c) 7200 joule – ❌ Too small
  • (d) 3600 calorie – ❌ 1 calorie = 4.184 J, so 3600 cal = only ~15,062 J

question:
Which is the Gaussian unit of kinematic viscosity?

SSC MTS 01/09/23 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The Gaussian unit (or CGS unit) of kinematic viscosity is Stokes.
  • Kinematic viscosity is defined as the ratio of dynamic viscosity to density.
  • In the CGS system:
    • 1 Stoke = 1 cm²/s

Option Analysis:

  • (a) Ampere – SI unit of electric current
  • (b) Joule – SI unit of work/energy
  • (c) Stokes – ✔ Correct unit for kinematic viscosity in the CGS system
  • (d) Darcy – Unit of permeability, not viscosity

Additional Information:

  • In the SI system, the unit of kinematic viscosity is m²/s
  • Often used in fluid mechanics to describe how easily a fluid flows under gravity

question:
The Units of Linear momentum are measured in ___________ .

SSC MTS 05/09/23 (1st shift)
option_1: Kg2 m/s
option_2: Kgm/s2
option_3: K2gm/s
solution:
• Linear momentum is defined as the product of an object's mass and velocity:
  • Momentum (p) = mass (m) × velocity (v)
  • SI Unit of:
    • Mass = kilogram (kg)
    • Velocity = meter per second (m/s)
    • ⇒ Therefore, unit of linear momentum = kg·m/s

Option Analysis:

  • (a) Kg²·m/s – ❌ Incorrect (mass squared is not applicable)
  • (b) Kg·m/s² – ❌ This is the unit of force (Newton)
  • (c) K2g·m/s – ❌ Typographical error and incorrect
  • (d) Kg·m/s – ✔Correct

Additional Information:

  • Linear momentum is a vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction).
  • It is conserved in isolated systems (law of conservation of momentum).

question:
Among the following pairs, which ones denote two scalar quantities?

SSC MTS 12/09/23 (2nd shift)
option_1: Momentum and Angular velocity
option_3: Linear momentum and Acceleration
option_4: Electric field and Force
solution:
• Scalar quantities have magnitude only, no direction.
  • Vector quantities have both magnitude and direction.

Let’s examine the pairs:

  • (a) Momentum and Angular velocity
    • Momentum → Vector
    • Angular velocity → Vector
    • ❌ Not scalar
  • (b) Distance and Speed
    • Distance → Scalar
    • Speed → Scalar
    • ✅Correct pair (both are scalar quantities)
  • (c) Linear momentum and Acceleration
    • Both are vector quantities
    • ❌ Not scalar
  • (d) Electric field and Force
    • Both are vector quantities
    • ❌ Not scalar

Correct Answer: (b)

Additional Information:

  • Displacement and velocity are vector counterparts of distance and speed.
  • Scalars are easier to compute as they do not require direction consideration.

question:
Identify the vector quantity among these listed physical quantities?

SSC MTS 14/09/23 (1st shift)
solution:
• A vector quantity is a physical quantity that has both magnitude and direction.
  • Let’s evaluate the given options:
    • (a) Energy → Scalar (only magnitude, no direction)
    • (b) Mass → Scalar (amount of matter, no direction)
    • (c) Density → Scalar (mass per unit volume, no direction)
    • (d) Gravitational Intensity → Vector (it has direction towards the center of mass)
  • Therefore, Gravitational Intensity is the correct vector quantity among the options.

Additional Information:

  • Gravitational Intensity is defined as the force per unit mass experienced by a small test mass in a gravitational field.
  • It is a vector because gravitational force has direction (always attractive).

question:
The number of significant figures in 0.05800 are:

SSC CHSL 08/08/23 (4th shift)
solution:
• Significant figures are the digits that carry meaning in a number and contribute to its precision.
  • Rules to count significant figures:
    1. Non-zero digits are always significant.
    2. Zeros between non-zero digits are significant.
    3. Leading zeros (zeros before the first non-zero digit) are not significant.
    4. Trailing zeros (zeros after a decimal point and a non-zero digit) are significant.

Now consider the number: 05800

  • Leading zeros: 0.0 → Not significant
  • Significant part: 5, 8, 0, 0 → Four significant figures

question:
The dimensions of force are:

SSC CHSL 14/08/23 (2nd shift)
option_1: [M0 L3 T0]
option_2: [M L-3 T0]
option_3: [M0 L T1]
solution:
• Force is defined by Newton's Second Law of Motion:
  • Force = Mass × Acceleration
  • Let's break down the dimensional formula of each component:
    • Mass (M) → [M]
    • Acceleration is defined as change in velocity per time →
    • Acceleration = Velocity / Time = (Length / Time) / Time = [L T⁻²]
  • So,
  • Force = Mass × Acceleration = [M] × [L T⁻²] = [M L T⁻²]

Additional Information:

  • Dimensional formula helps in checking correctness of physical equations.
  • SI unit of force is newton (N) = kg·m/s²
  • 1 newton is the force that gives a 1 kg mass an acceleration of 1 m/s².

question:
Seismograph is used to measure:

SSC CGL 17/07/23 (2nd shift)
solution:
• A Seismograph is an instrument used to detect and record seismic waves.
  • These waves are generated by earthquakes or other ground vibrations.
  • It records the motion of the ground in the form of a seismogram.

Additional Information:

  • The study of earthquakes is called Seismology.
  • The magnitude of an earthquake is measured using the Richter scale.
  • Seismographs are typically installed in earthquake-prone regions for early warning and research.

question:
A non-SI unit called ‘nit’ is the unit of which of the following photometric quantities used to measure a multitude of light intensity?

SSC CGL 18/07/23 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Nit is a non-SI unit used to measure luminance.
  • Luminance refers to the brightness of a surface, i.e., how much light is emitted or reflected in a particular direction per unit area.
  • 1 nit = 1 candela per square meter (cd/m²).

Additional Information:

  • Luminous exposure: Measured in lux-seconds, it represents the total luminous energy per unit area.
  • Luminosity: Refers to the total amount of energy emitted by a light source per unit time; it's more common in astronomy.
  • Luminous emittance: Amount of light emitted from a surface per unit area, measured in lumens/m² (lux).
  • Luminance is important in display technologies, such as screens, monitors, and TVs.

question:
What is the an instrument that sends pulses of electromagnetic energy into the atmosphere to detect rainfall, determine its speed and intensity, and identify precipitation types such as rain, snow or hail?

SSC CGL 21/07/23 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is Doppler weather radar.
  • A Doppler weather radar emits pulses of electromagnetic waves into the atmosphere to detect precipitation.
  • It measures:
    • Location of rain or snow
    • Intensity of precipitation
    • Speed and direction of movement (using the Doppler effect)
    • Type of precipitation (rain, snow, hail)

Additional Information:

  • Barometer: Measures atmospheric pressure.
  • Spectral pyranometer: Measures solar radiation.
  • 2D sonic anemometer: Measures wind speed and direction using ultrasonic sound waves.
  • Doppler radar is essential for weather forecasting and storm tracking, especially for identifying cyclones and thunderstorms.

question:
Which physical unit is defined as the field intensity that produces one newton (N) of force per ampere (A) per meter of the conductor?

SSC CGL 26/07/23 (4th shift)
solution:
• The unit described in the question is Tesla (T).
  • Tesla is the SI unit of magnetic field strength or magnetic flux density.
  • It is defined as:
    • 1 Tesla = 1 Newton per Ampere per meter
    • That means a magnetic field of 1 Tesla exerts a force of 1 N on a conductor carrying 1 A of current over a length of 1 m.

Additional Information:

  • Candela: SI unit of luminous intensity.
  • Coulomb (not "Coolam"): SI unit of electric charge.
  • Pascal: SI unit of pressure (1 Pa = 1 N/m²).
  • Tesla is named after the inventor Nikola Tesla and is commonly used in electromagnetism and MRI technologies.

question:
Name the instrument that is used by meteorologists to measure the solar radiation from the region of the hemisphere of incidence on a flat surface?

Matric Level 27/06/23 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct instrument is Pyranometer.
  • A pyranometer is used to measure solar radiation falling on a horizontal flat surface.
  • It measures global solar irradiance, i.e., the sum of direct and diffuse solar radiation from the hemisphere of the sky.

Additional Information:

  • Hygrometer: Measures humidity in the atmosphere.
  • Barometer: Measures atmospheric pressure.
  • Anemometer: Measures wind speed.
  • Pyranometers are commonly used in meteorology, climatology, and solar energy studies to assess sunlight availability.

question:
Match the points under List I with those under List II.

SSC CHSL Tier-II 26/06/23


https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image001.png
solution:
We need to match each instrument from List-I with its correct function in List-II:

  1. Sextant → a. Measures the angle between two visible objects
    • A sextant is a navigational instrument used in astronomy and maritime travel to measure angles between celestial objects and the horizon.
  2. Udometer → d. Measures the amount of rainfall
    • Udometer is another name for a rain gauge, used in meteorology to collect and measure the amount of liquid precipitation.
  3. Thermopile → b. Measures small quantities of radiant heat
    • A thermopile is an electronic device that converts thermal energy into electrical energy, sensitive to radiant heat.
  4. Pyrometer → c. Measures the temperature of surface
    • A pyrometer is used to measure high temperatures from a distance, especially the surface temperature of hot objects.

Correct Matching:

  • 1 → a
  • 2 → d
  • 3 → b
  • 4 → c

Correct Option: (b)

question:
The unit of magnetic intensity in the CGS (centimeter-gram-second) system is _________ .

SSC CHSL Tier-II 26/06/23
solution:
• Magnetic intensity (also called magnetic field strength) in the CGS system is measured in Oersted (Oe).
  • It is different from magnetic flux density, which is measured in Gauss in the CGS system.
  • 1 Oersted corresponds to the magnetic field strength that would produce a magnetic flux density of 1 Gauss in vacuum.
  • The SI unit of magnetic intensity is A/m (Ampere per meter).
  • The Candela is the SI unit of luminous intensity, and Weber is the SI unit of magnetic flux — neither is related to magnetic field strength in CGS.

Additional Information:

  • 1 Oersted ≈ 79.5775 A/m
  • 1 Gauss = 10⁻⁴ Tesla (unit of magnetic flux density in SI)
  • In CGS:
    • Magnetic field strength → Oersted
    • Magnetic flux density → Gauss

question:
The wind vane instrument measures the _________ .

SSC MTS 15/05/23 (Morning)
solution:
• A wind vane is a meteorological instrument used to measure wind direction.
  • It is typically mounted on rooftops or open fields and rotates to show the direction from which the wind is blowing.
  • It is often used along with an anemometer, which measures wind speed (velocity).
  • Relative humidity is measured by a hygrometer, and temperature is measured using a thermometer.

Additional Information:

  • The arrow of the wind vane points into the wind, meaning it shows the origin of the wind.
  • Wind direction is usually expressed in terms like north wind (from the north), southwest wind, etc.

question:
Which among the following is a unit of measurement that describes the rate at which the universe is expanding?

SSC CHSL 31/03/23 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Hubble constant is the unit of measurement that describes the rate at which the universe is expanding.
  • It relates the velocity of a galaxy’s recession (due to expansion) to its distance from Earth:
  • v = H₀ × d,
  • where H₀ is the Hubble constant.
  • Its unit is typically km/s/Mpc (kilometers per second per megaparsec).
  • The concept was proposed by Edwin Hubble in the 1920s based on observations of redshifted galaxies.

Additional Information:

  • Faraday constant relates to the amount of electric charge per mole of electrons.
  • Planck’s constant is fundamental in quantum mechanics.
  • Electric constant (ε₀) refers to permittivity of free space in electromagnetism.

question:
Match the columns.

SSC CGL Tier-II 07/03/23


https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image002.png
option_1: i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d
option_2: i-b, ii-a, iii-c, iv-d
option_3: i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a
option_4: i-a, ii-c, iii-b, iv-d
solution:
We need to match physical quantities with their SI units:

Column – A:

i. Electric current →

ii. Potential difference →

iii. Capacitance →

iv. Inductance →

Column – B:

a. Henry

b. Farad

c. Volt

d. Ampere

Matching them correctly:

  • i. Electric current → d. Ampere
  • ii. Potential difference → c. Volt
  • iii. Capacitance → b. Farad
  • iv. Inductance → a. Henry

So, the correct sequence is:

i-d, ii-c, iii-b, iv-a → This corresponds to Option (c).

question:
What is the numerical value of a physical quantity?

SSC CGL 06/12/22 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The numerical value of a physical quantity refers to its magnitude.
  • A physical quantity is expressed as:
  • Physical quantity = Numerical value × Unit
  • For example, if a rod is 5 meters long, then:
    • Numerical value = 5
    • Unit = meter
    • Magnitude = 5 (it tells us “how much”)

Additional Information:

  • Reference refers to a baseline or comparison standard.
  • Direction is relevant in vector quantities but not the numerical value itself.
  • Distance is a type of physical quantity, not the definition of a numerical value.

question:
What is the commercial unit of electric energy?

SSC CGL 06/12/22 (4th shift)
solution:
• The commercial unit of electric energy is the kilowatt hour (kWh).
  • It is commonly used by electricity boards for billing purposes.
  • 1 kilowatt hour means using 1000 watts of power for 1 hour.

Additional Information:

  • Watt-hour is a smaller unit and not commonly used commercially.
  • Watt per hour and Kilowatt per hour are incorrect terms — they imply rate of change of power, which is not meaningful here.
  • Electricity meters measure consumption in kWh.

https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image003.png

question:
Which of the following is a unit of distance?

SSC CGL 07/12/22 (1st shift)
solution:
• A light year is the distance that light travels in one year in a vacuum.
  • It is commonly used in astronomy to measure vast distances between celestial objects.
  • 1 light year ≈ 9.46 × 10¹² kilometers.
  • Other options:
    • Newton – SI unit of force.
    • Watt – SI unit of power.
    • Joule – SI unit of energy.

Additional Information:

  • The SI unit of distance is meter.
  • Light travels at a speed of 3 × 10⁸ m/s in a vacuum.
  • Larger astronomical units:
    • Astronomical Unit (AU) ≈ distance from Earth to Sun (~149.6 million km)
    • Parsec ≈ 3.26 light years

question:
Which measuring instrument consists of a metal triangular frame supported on three legs, used to measure the radius of curvature of an object such as lenses and curved mirrors which are spherical in shape?

SSC CGL 12/12/22 (4th shift)
solution:
• A spherometer is a device used to measure the radius of curvature of spherical surfaces such as lenses and mirrors.
  • It consists of a metal triangular frame with three legs forming a tripod, and a central screw that moves vertically.
  • This central screw has a calibrated scale to measure height (h) from the curved surface, which is used in the formula for calculating radius of curvature:

  • Other instruments:
    • Viscometer – Measures viscosity of liquids.
    • Vernier Caliper – Measures internal/external diameters, depth.
    • Screw Gauge – Measures very small thicknesses (e.g. wire diameter).

Additional Information:

  • Spherometers are widely used in optical workshops and physics labs.
  • Highly precise versions may use micrometer screws for better accuracy.

https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image004.png

question:
What is the defined value of KB in the given equation?

KB = PV/TN

SSC CPO 09/11/22 (1st shift)
option_1:
1.38 10-23 JK-1
https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image005.png
option_2:
1.08 10-23 JK-1
https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image005.png
option_3:
1.68 10-23 JK-1
https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image005.png
option_4:
0.38 10-23 JK-1
https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image005.png
solution:
• The given equation is KB = PV / TN, which relates to the ideal gas law.
  • From the ideal gas equation: PV = NkB T, where:
    • P = Pressure
    • V = Volume
    • N = Number of molecules
    • T = Temperature in Kelvin
    • kB = Boltzmann constant
  • Rearranging the formula:
  • kB = PV / (NT) – which matches the given equation.
  • The Boltzmann constant (kB) is a fundamental physical constant that relates the average kinetic energy of particles in a gas with the temperature of the gas.
  • The defined value of kB is:
  • kB = 1.38 × 10⁻²³ J/K

Additional Information:

  • Boltzmann constant plays a key role in statistical mechanics.
  • It bridges macroscopic thermodynamic quantities with microscopic molecular behavior.
  • It is also used in the equation for entropy:
  • S = kB ln(Ω)

question:
How is the voltmeter connected across the points between which the potential difference is to be measured?

SSC CHSL 30/05/22 (Afternoon)
option_1: Along the same magnetic field
option_4: Perpendicular to each other
solution:
• A voltmeter is an instrument used to measure potential difference (voltage) between two points in an electric circuit.
  • To measure voltage accurately, the voltmeter must not draw current, or should draw very minimal current.
  • Therefore, it is connected in parallel with the component or section of the circuit across which the voltage is to be measured.
  • Parallel connection ensures that the voltage across the voltmeter is the same as the voltage across the circuit component.

Additional Information:

  • A voltmeter ideally has very high resistance to prevent current flow through it.
  • If connected in series, it would alter the circuit current and give incorrect readings.
  • Common voltmeters include analog (needle-based) and digital voltmeters.

question:
Which of the following is the physical quantity for the expression arc/radius?

SSC CGL 18/04/22 (1st shift)
solution:
• The given expression is arc / radius, which is the formula to calculate a plane angle in radians.
  • Plane angle (θ) in radians is defined as:
    • θ = arc length (s) / radius (r)
  • This ratio is dimensionless but it represents a physical quantity called plane angle.

Additional Information:

  • SI unit of plane angle is radian (rad).
  • 1 complete circle = 2π radians = 360°
  • Plane angle is used in rotational motion, circular motion, and trigonometry.

question:
Of the units mentioned in the options, which one is the largest as compared to the others?

SSC MTS 05/10/21 (Evening)
solution:
• The question asks for the largest unit among the given options.
  • These are metric prefixes used to denote powers of 10:

Prefix

Symbol

Value

Deca

da

10¹ = 10

Hecto

h

10² = 100

Giga

G

10⁹ = 1,000,000,000

Tera

T

10¹² = 1,000,000,000,000

  • Comparing values:
    • Tera > Giga > Hecto > Deca

Additional Information:

  • These prefixes are commonly used in measurements like:
    • Tera: Terabyte (data)
    • Giga: Gigahertz, Gigabyte
    • Hecto: Hectopascal (pressure)
    • Deca: Decameter (length)

question:
What is the unit to measure the wavelength of light?

SSC MTS 12/10/21 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The wavelength of light is typically measured in very small units due to its microscopic size.
  • The most common unit used is the Angstrom (Å).
  • 1 Angstrom = 10⁻¹⁰ meters
  • Visible light has wavelengths ranging approximately from:
    • 4000 Å (violet) to 7000 Å (red)
  • Other units like nanometers (nm) are also used, but among the given options, Angstrom is the correct one.

Additional Information:

  • Faraday: Unit of electric charge (not used for wavelength)
  • Candela: SI unit of luminous intensity (brightness)
  • Dyne: CGS unit of force
  • Angstrom: Used in atomic physics, molecular structures, and spectroscopy to measure very small lengths like wavelength.

question:
Which of the following has the same dimension as that of linear momentum?

SSC CGL 13/08/21 (1st shift)
solution:
• Linear momentum (p) is defined as:
  • p = mass × velocity
  • → SI unit: kg·m/s
  • → Dimensional formula: [M¹L¹T⁻¹]
  • Now check dimensions of the given options:
    1. Impulse = Force × Time
      • Force = mass × acceleration = [M¹L¹T⁻²]
      • Time = [T¹]
      • Impulse = [M¹L¹T⁻¹] → Same as momentum
    2. Stress = Force / Area
      • = [M¹L⁻¹T⁻²]
    3. Work / Energy = Force × Displacement
      • = [M¹L²T⁻²]
  • So, only Impulse has the same dimensional formula as linear momentum.

Additional Information:

  • Impulse is also defined as the change in momentum.
  • Impulse and momentum are closely related through Newton's second law:
  • Impulse = Δ(momentum)

question:
Electron-volt is a unit of ________ .

SSC CGL 13/08/21 (1st shift)
solution:
• The electron-volt (eV) is a unit of energy, not current, power, or potential difference.
  • It is defined as the amount of energy gained or lost by an electron when it moves through an electric potential difference of 1 volt.
  • 1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ joules

Explanation:

  • When 1 electron (charge = 6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) is accelerated by 1 volt:
    • Energy = Charge × Voltage
    • = (1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) × (1 V) = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J

Additional Information:

  • Electron-volt is commonly used in atomic, nuclear, and particle physics.
  • It is useful for expressing small energy values at the subatomic scale.

question:
“Svedberg Unit” is a unit of _________ ?

SSC CGL 13/08/21 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Svedberg unit (symbol: S) is a unit of time, not size, concentration, or density.
  • It is used to express the sedimentation rate of particles (like ribosomes) during ultracentrifugation.
  • It measures how fast a particle sediments when spun at high speed.
  • 1 Svedberg (1 S) = 10⁻¹³ seconds

Explanation:

  • Although it appears related to size, the Svedberg unit actually reflects a particle’s sedimentation velocity, which depends on mass, shape, and density.
  • For example, the 70S and 80S ribosomes refer to their sedimentation coefficients, not additive sizes.

Additional Information:

  • Named after Theodor Svedberg, who studied colloids and developed ultracentrifugation.
  • Common in molecular biology, especially in describing ribosomal subunits (e.g., 30S, 50S, 70S).

question:
Weber per second is equivalent to _________ .

SSC CGL 18/08/21 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The unit Weber (Wb) is the SI unit of magnetic flux.
  • When we talk about Weber per second (Wb/s), we are referring to the rate of change of magnetic flux.
  • According to Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction:
  • Induced EMF (Voltage) = – dΦ/dt, where:
    • Φ (Phi) is magnetic flux (in Weber)
    • dΦ/dt is change of flux per second → unit is Weber/second
  • Therefore, Weber/second = Volt

Additional Information:

  • 1 Wb/s = 1 V
  • This relationship forms the basis of how generators produce voltage via changing magnetic fields.

question:
In terms of SI prefixes 10-15 is called:

SSC CGL 24/08/21 (Afternoon)
solution:
• SI prefixes are used to express very large or very small quantities in powers of 10.
  • The prefix for 10⁻¹⁵ is Femto (f).

Prefix

Symbol

Power of 10

Femto

f

10⁻¹⁵

Atto

a

10⁻¹⁸

Zepto

z

10⁻²¹

Yocto

y

10⁻²⁴

  • Therefore, 10⁻¹⁵ = Femto

Additional Information:

  • Femto is used in fields like physics and femtochemistry (study of reactions on the scale of femtoseconds).
  • 1 femtosecond = 10⁻¹⁵ seconds

question:
The difference in temperature between two bodies is 30 degree centigrade. What is the difference in degree Fahrenheit?

SSC CPO 23/11/20 (1st shift)
solution:
• To convert a temperature difference from Celsius to Fahrenheit, we use the formula:

question:
‘mho’ is the unit of ______ of a substance.

SSC CPO 25/11/20 (1st shift)
solution:
• The unit ‘mho’ is the inverse of ohm, used to measure how easily electricity can pass through a substance.
  • The property it measures is called conductance, which is the reciprocal of resistance.
  • Formula:
  • Conductance (G) = 1 / Resistance (R)
  • Unit of resistance = ohm (Ω)
  • So, unit of conductance = 1/ohm = mho
  • The modern SI unit for conductance is siemens (S), but ‘mho’ is still used in older contexts.

Additional Information:

  • Conductance is denoted by G and is measured in mho or siemens (S).
  • Resistance is denoted by R and measured in ohm (Ω).
  • Conductance increases as resistance decreases, i.e., a good conductor like copper has high conductance and low resistance.

question:
One calorie of heat energy is equivalent to approximately _________ joules of mechanical Energy.

SSC CPO 25/11/20 (1st shift)
solution:
• Calorie is a unit of heat energy, whereas joule is the SI unit of energy/work.
  • The standard conversion is:
  • 1 calorie ≈ 4.184 joules
  • In most competitive exams and practical uses, it is approximated as:
  • 1 calorie ≈ 4.2 joules
  • This value shows how much mechanical energy (in joules) is equivalent to 1 calorie of heat energy.

Additional Information:

  • The calorie is commonly used in thermodynamics and nutrition (food energy).
  • In physics, the joule is preferred as the standard unit of energy.
  • The mechanical equivalent of heat is the concept that heat and mechanical energy are interchangeable, first demonstrated by James Prescott Joule.

question:
30 Celcius = _______ Kelvin (approximately).

SSC CPO 25/11/20 (1st shift)


https://appx-content-v2.classx.co.in/website/bulk_uploader_images/1749722926232_image009.png
solution:
• The Kelvin (K) scale is the SI unit of temperature.
  • To convert Celsius to Kelvin, use the formula:
  • K = °C + 273.15
  • So,
  • 30°C + 273.15 ≈ 303.15 K
  • Approximated as 303 K

Additional Information:

  • 0°C = 273.15 K
  • Kelvin scale starts from absolute zero (0 K), where all molecular motion theoretically stops.
  • This conversion is commonly used in thermodynamics and scientific calculations.

question: The SI unit of length is
solution:
• The SI unit of length is the meter (m).
  • Meter is the standard unit used worldwide to measure length or distance.
  • It is defined based on the speed of light: one meter is the distance light travels in vacuum in 1/299,792,458 seconds.
  • The meter is used for measuring small distances (with prefixes like centimeter, millimeter) as well as large distances (kilometer).
  • It is a fundamental unit in the International System of Units (SI).

Additional Information:

  • Other units like centimeter and kilometer are derived from the meter.
  • Inch is a non-SI unit commonly used in some countries like the USA.

question: Which instrument is used to measure the mass of an object?
solution:
• The instrument used to measure the mass of an object is the beam balance.
  • A beam balance compares the mass of the object with known standard masses on the opposite side of a balanced beam.
  • It is widely used in laboratories and schools for accurate measurement of mass.
  • Unlike weight, which depends on gravity, mass is the amount of matter in the object and remains constant regardless of location.
  • Other instruments listed, like thermometer, stopwatch, and vernier caliper, measure temperature, time, and length/dimensions respectively.

Additional Information:

  • Mass is measured in kilograms (kg) or grams (g) in the SI system.
  • Electronic balances are modern alternatives but beam balances are still widely used for their simplicity and accuracy.

question: The fundamental quantity among the following is
solution:
• Among the given options, time is a fundamental quantity.
  • Fundamental quantities are basic physical quantities that cannot be derived from other quantities.
  • Time is one of the seven fundamental quantities in the International System of Units (SI).
  • Speed, distance, and temperature are either derived quantities or measured using fundamental quantities.
  • Time is measured in seconds (s) in the SI system.

Additional Information:

  • Distance is a fundamental quantity too, but in this question, time is the correct choice as per standard options.
  • Speed is a derived quantity defined as distance divided by time.
  • Temperature is also a fundamental quantity, but if the question focuses on SI base quantities, time is among the primary ones.
